div.p: >> Hi. This is Joyce Farrell.
Let's look at gui components.

Gui components are
all the little icons

and pictorial devices
you're used
to using with many programs.

They're graphical
user interfaces.

That is, they're pictures
that the user can use
to interact with a program.

They include things like
buttons, labels, and text boxes.
When you program a gui program,

you frequently use an integrated
development environment,

which is an environment
that makes it easy for you

to manipulate items
like buttons and labels.

Here's a demonstration program
that allows you to enter a name.
Let's say I type in a name

and when I click the
button, there's a greeting.

It has a label, a text box,
a button and another label.

This is the Microsoft
Visual C Sharp integrated
development environment.

There are different integrated
development environments

for other programming languages,
but this one is quite typical.

There's a form here in
the middle that I can use
to start my application.

And over here, there are some
gui components like a button

and a check box that I
can drag onto the form
to create my application.

Right now, the name of
this form is Form 1.

And if you look over
here, the properties

of Form 1 include the fact
that its text is Form 1.

Well, I don't want its text
to be Form 1, so I'm going

to delete that and I'm
going to type demonstration.

When I press Enter,
or click back on Form,
it's going to say demonstration.

Let me take a gui component
like a label and drag it here.

And right now, the
label's name is Label 1
and its text is Label 1,

but I want to change its
text to be: enter a name.
And there it is.
Enter a name.

Let me get a text box and put
it next to that and that's

where the user will
be entering the name.

I'm not going to change
the text in the text box

because I want the
user to do that.

I'm going to get
button and drag it here.

And I don't want the button
to say Button 1, so I'm going

to change its text
to say: click here.

And then finally, I want
a label here that's going

to greet the user, so I'm going
to put another label there.
It's called Label 2.

I don't want its
text to say label 2,

I actually want its text to
start out saying nothing.

So I'm just going
to delete its text.

Also, that label is kind of
small, so under the properties

of Label 2, I'm going to scroll
up -- and let's find its font

and instead of 8, let's make
it something a little bit more
noticeable like 24.

OK. So now I have a
label, a text box,
a button and another label.

In order to get some
actions, I need to write code

for what happens when the
user clicks the button.

If I double click the button,
I can get to some C Sharp code.

Now you'd have to
learn a lot of C Sharp

to understand what
everything here means.

But right now, I just need
to add a single statement
to the Button 1 click method.

This is the method
that will execute
when Button 1 is clicked.

What I want to do is change
the text in that Label 2.

So I start typing
Label 2, and when I do,

the automatic statement
completion feature

of C Sharp helps me out
by giving me some choices

and I can just double
click on Label 2

and then I can set its text to
Hello, with a comma and a space,

plus whatever the user
has typed in text Box 1.
That will be Text Box 1's text.

In C Sharp, every statement
ends with a semicolon,
so I'll type a semicolon.

Looking back at the form,
there's still nothing there

in Label 2 because the user
hasn't clicked a button yet.
We haven't run the program yet.

To run the program, one way is
to go to debug and pick Start.
The form shows up.

It's ready for me
to enter a name.

I'm going to type a name
and click the button.
And there's the greeting.
If I type a different name,

click the button,
there's the greeting.

That's a quick look
at how you might start

to create an application
using gui components.
